topic: Fundamental Tagalog Grammar Rules for Learners

rules.name: Roots and Affixes
rules.description: Roots combined with affixes form various words; affixes change meaning and grammatical role.

rules.name: Sentence Structure
rules.description: Tagalog word order differs from English; subject marking via particle markers (e.g., ang).

rules.name: Pronunciation and Sounds
rules.description: Certain vowel sounds can be interchanged in spoken Filipino.
rules.common_errors: Not explicitly stated, but note that changes occur only in spoken forms.

rules.name: Syllable Repetition
rules.description: Syllable repetition is a pattern in verb conjugation (future tense).

rules.name: Markers (ang, ng, sa)
rules.description: Markers indicate grammatical roles such as subject focus, possession, and direction.

rules.name: Gender Neutrality
rules.description: Filipino nouns and pronouns are generally gender-neutral.
examples: Siya yung sinasabi ko. (He/She was the one I was talking about.)

rules.name: Plurals
rules.description: Plural nouns use the marker "mga" before the noun.

rules.name: Ang Pronouns
rules.description: Pronouns that serve as subject focus in sentences.

rules.name: Ng Pronouns
rules.description: Pronouns for possessive or unfocused actors.

rules.name: Sa Pronouns
rules.description: Pronouns indicating location, direction, or possession.

rules.name: Kita
rules.description: Special pronoun for combinations like I–you.

rules.name: Verb Groups
rules.description: Verbs are grouped by affixes (mag-, ma-, um-, in-, i-).

rules.name: Verb Repetition for Prolonged Action
rules.description: Repeated verbs with "nang" express ongoing actions.
examples: Kain nang kain si Raul. (Raul keeps on eating.)

rules.name: Adjective-Noun Identicals
rules.description: Some adjectives have the same spelling as nouns but differ in pronunciation.

rules.name: Adjective Gender
rules.description: Certain adjectives change form based on gender (commonly end in -a for female).

rules.name: Degrees of Adjectives
rules.description: Adjectives intensify through repetition or addition of prefixes.

rules.name: Typical Word Order (V-S-O)
rules.description: Tagalog generally uses a Verb-Subject-Object order rather than English’s S-V-O, which emphasizes the action first.

examples.Formal Order: Si Maria ay nag-aaral ng Tagalog

rules.name: Declarative Sentences
rules.description: Use verb-first to state facts.
rules.common_errors: Using S-V-O order like English learners tend to do

rules.name: Interrogative Sentences
rules.description: Questions place the predicate/verb or phrase before the subject and subject particle.
rules.common_errors: Incorrect placement of ‘ba’ before the predicate

rules.name: Imperative Sentences
rules.description: Commands typically start with the verb followed by the subject.
rules.common_errors: Placing subject first like English (‘Ikaw pumasok’)

rules.name: Exclamatory Sentences
rules.description: Express emotion by leading with the adjective or predicate followed by the particle.

rules.name: Connectors for Compound Ideas
rules.description: Tagalog uses connectors such as *at* (and) and *dahil/kasi* (because) to link ideas.

examples.English: I’m tired because I worked all day

rules.name: Applying English Word Order
rules.description: English learners often incorrectly use English structures, which can make sentences sound unnatural.

examples.Correct: Gusto ko ng prutas at gulay

rules.common_errors: Using English word order or misusing connectors

rules.name: Overuse of “ay”
rules.description: Learners often overuse the particle *ay*. It’s typically for emphasis or formal contexts, not everyday speech.
rules.common_errors: Overusing ‘ay’ in casual sentences

rules.name: Quiz Corrections
rules.description: Example learner sentences with corrections to reinforce correct structure.
rules.common_errors: Direct translation from English structures

topic: Filipino Grammar for the Beginning Learner

rules.name: Active vs Non-Active Verb Affixes
rules.description: Filipino verbs are conjugated using affixes for active and non-active voices.

rules.name: Plurality in Verbs
rules.description: Verbs do not change with number in everyday Filipino.
rules.common_errors: Assuming plural must always change verb form

rules.name: Passive Voice Usage
rules.description: Passive constructions are often more natural in Filipino than direct active voice.

examples.Formal Active: Ako ay umiinom ng kape araw-araw
examples.note: More formal but uncommon in speech

rules.name: Basic Tense/Aspect Categories
rules.description: Filipino tenses are often described as aspects: completed (past), incompleted (present), contemplative (future).

examples.English: I will watch a movie tomorrow

rules.name: Imperative and Infinitive
rules.description: Imperative and infinitive forms use the same conjugation patterns but are conditioned by markers/hints in context.

rules.name: Recent Perfective Aspect
rules.description: Indicates actions completed just before speaking; applies mainly to actor-focus verbs.

rules.name: Personal Pronoun Cases
rules.description: Pronouns vary by case (nominative, possessive, objective). Some include special forms (e.g., kita).
rules.common_errors: Confusing pronoun forms by case

rules.name: Case Markers (Ang/Ng/Sa)
rules.description: Markers indicate grammatical roles such as subject focus, possession, and direction.
rules.common_errors: Misplacing markers due to English assumptions

rules.name: Verb Focus and Affix Choice
rules.description: Choosing the proper affix depends on which component (actor, object, etc.) you want to focus on.

examples.English: It was rice that I ate (object focus)

rules.common_errors: Using affixes without considering focus

topic: Filipino Grammar Rules — Quick Online Learning

rules.name: Verb–Subject–Object Order
rules.description: In Filipino, the verb typically comes before the subject and object, unlike English’s subject–verb–object order.
rules.common_errors: Forgetting the verb-first order and applying English SVO directly.

rules.name: Use of ‘ay’ for Formality
rules.description: The copula ‘ay’ is used to form more formal or emphatic sentences.

examples.Filipino: Si Juan ay maganda ang boses.

rules.common_errors: Overusing ‘ay’ in everyday informal speech.

rules.name: Personal Pronouns
rules.description: Filipino personal pronouns change depending on case (subject, object, possessive).
rules.common_errors: Confusing pronoun forms in object vs possessive use.

rules.name: Plural Pronouns
rules.description: Pronouns also indicate inclusive vs exclusive first-person plural.
rules.common_errors: Mixing up inclusive and exclusive ‘we’ forms.

rules.name: Markers ‘ang’, ‘ng’, and ‘sa’
rules.description: Filipino uses markers to show grammatical roles. ‘Ang’ marks the focus of the sentence, ‘ng’ shows possession or non-focused actors/objects, and ‘sa’ indicates direction or indirect objects.
rules.common_errors: Misplacing case markers by directly translating English noun roles.

rules.name: Plural with ‘mga’
rules.description: To make a noun plural, ‘mga’ is placed before the noun.
rules.common_errors: Forgetting to use ‘mga’ for plural nouns.

rules.name: Use of Verb Affixes
rules.description: Filipino verbs are formed with affixes that indicate tense/aspect and focus.
rules.common_errors: Using verb roots without appropriate affixes.

rules.name: Aspect over Tense
rules.description: Verb forms in Filipino indicate aspect (complete, ongoing, future) rather than strict grammatical tense.
rules.common_errors: Applying English tense rules directly.

rules.name: Adjective Placement
rules.description: Adjectives generally come before the noun they modify in Filipino.
rules.common_errors: Switching to English word order.

rules.name: Adverb Formation
rules.description: Many Filipino adverbs are formed by affixing or repeating words to express manner or degree.

rules.name: Forming Yes/No Questions
rules.description: Yes/no questions often use particles like ‘ba’ to indicate inquiry.
rules.common_errors: Omitting the question particle in direct translations.

rules.name: Negation with ‘hindi’ and ‘wala’
rules.description: ‘Hindi’ is used to negate verbs and equational sentences; ‘wala’ indicates absence.

topic: Common Filipino Language Mistakes and How to Avoid Them

grammar_mistakes.name: Incorrect Syllabication (Pronunciation)
grammar_mistakes.description: Mispronouncing Filipino words by incorrectly syllabicating them because of influence from one’s native language.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Carrying over accent and stress from native language into Filipino syllabication.

grammar_mistakes.name: Confusion between ng and nang
grammar_mistakes.description: Using “ng” and “nang” interchangeably when they have distinct grammatical roles.

examples.meaning: Jed is the owner of the car.

examples.sentence: Naliligo ako nang biglang may kumatok sa pinto.
examples.meaning: I was bathing when someone suddenly knocked on the door.

examples.sentence: Kain ka nang kain hindi ka naman tumataba.
examples.meaning: All you do is eat, yet you don’t gain weight.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Using “nang” when “ng” should be used or vice versa.

grammar_mistakes.name: Kumusta vs. Kamusta (Vocabulary)
grammar_mistakes.description: Misunderstanding the appropriateness of 'kumusta' vs. 'kamusta.'
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Using “kamusta” in formal contexts where “kumusta” is considered more correct.

grammar_mistakes.name: Barok Speak and Word Order Errors
grammar_mistakes.description: Omitting linking words or inappropriate word placement, leading to awkward or incomplete Filipino sentences.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Leaving out “si/ang/ay” and other necessary linkers in sentences.

grammar_mistakes.name: Incorrect Use of the Particle ‘ba’
grammar_mistakes.description: Placing the question particle *ba* in the wrong spot in interrogative sentences.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Placing *ba* in positions that make the sentence sound awkward.

grammar_mistakes.name: Mix-up of ikaw, ka, and mo
grammar_mistakes.description: Confusing the pronouns *ikaw*, *ka*, and *mo* and their appropriate placements.

examples.incorrect: Kumain na ikaw habang maaga pa.
examples.correct: Kumain ka na habang maaga pa.
examples.meaning: Go eat while it’s still early.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Interchanging pronouns or placing them incorrectly in sentences.

grammar_mistakes.name: Verb Conjugation with Affixes
grammar_mistakes.description: Incorrectly choosing verb affixes (e.g., using *mag-* when the verb requires *-um*).
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Using the wrong affix when forming verb tenses and aspects.

grammar_mistakes.name: Confusing Daw vs. Raw
grammar_mistakes.description: Using *daw* and *raw* without regard to the sound that precedes them.

examples.correct: Kumain daw kayo kina Andrew kagabi?
examples.meaning: They said you ate at Andrew’s last night.
They said they’re already in Manila.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Using *daw/raw* without matching them to the phonetic rule (preceding consonant/vowel).

grammar_mistakes.name: Bukod vs. Maliban (Vocabulary Usage)
grammar_mistakes.description: *Bukod* and *maliban* have different meanings (“in addition to” vs “except”) and are often interchanged incorrectly.

examples.incorrect: Maliban sa Master’s Degree, mayroon din siyang Doctor’s Degree.
examples.correct: Bukod sa Master’s Degree, mayroon din siyang Doctor’s Degree.

examples.incorrect: Lahat ng anak ni Alfonso ay nagtapos na ng kolehiyo bukod kay Mateo.
examples.correct: Lahat ng anak ni Alfonso ay nagtapos na ng kolehiyo maliban kay Mateo.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Using the wrong word to express addition vs exception.

grammar_mistakes.name: Kung vs. Kapag (Conditional vs Temporal)
grammar_mistakes.description: Confusing *kung* (“if”) and *kapag* (“when”) and their proper use depending on the sentence context.

examples.correct: Paano kung hindi ko maabutan ang tren bukas?
examples.meaning: What if I miss the train tomorrow?

examples.correct: Uuwi lang ako kapag tinawag na ako ni nanay.
examples.meaning: I’ll go home when mom calls me.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Interchanging *kung* and *kapag* regardless of cause/effect or time context.

grammar_mistakes.name: Not Practicing Enough
grammar_mistakes.description: Failing to practice Filipino regularly — the biggest mistake for language learners.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Neglecting regular speaking, listening, writing practice.

topic: 11 Common Filipino Grammar Mistakes We Use Incorrectly

grammar_mistakes.name: Kumusta vs. Kamusta
grammar_mistakes.description: Using “Kamusta” instead of the more formal/correct “Kumusta”, especially in writing or formal contexts.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Using 'Kamusta' in formal writing where 'Kumusta' is preferred.

grammar_mistakes.name: Sila vs. Sina
grammar_mistakes.description: Confusing the pronoun 'sila' (they/them) with 'sina' (used to introduce proper names).

examples.usage: Parating na sina Pedro at Juan.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Using 'sina' and 'sila' interchangeably without regard to context.

grammar_mistakes.name: Daw vs. Raw
grammar_mistakes.description: Using 'daw' and 'raw' without the phonetic rule; choice depends on the sound before the word.

examples.sentence: Dumaan daw kayo sa bahay kahapon?
Si Mika raw ang nagluto ng hapunan.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Applying daw/raw incorrectly regardless of preceding sound.

grammar_mistakes.name: Ng vs. Nang
grammar_mistakes.description: Confusing the preposition 'ng' with the conjunction 'nang'.

examples.usage: Ang may-ari ng laptop na ito ay si Jed.
examples.English: The owner of this laptop is Jed.

examples.usage: Nagluluto ako nang biglang may kumatok sa aming pinto.
examples.English: I was cooking when someone knocked on our door.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Interchanging 'ng' and 'nang' without regard to grammatical role.

grammar_mistakes.name: Bukod vs. Maliban
grammar_mistakes.description: Using 'bukod' for addition and 'maliban' for exception but often mixing them up.

examples.correct: Bukod sa pagsasayaw, marunong din siya kumanta.
examples.English: Besides dancing, she can also sing.

examples.correct: Lahat ng anak niya ay pintor maliban sa kanyang bunso.
examples.English: All his children are painters except his youngest child.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Using the wrong word to express addition vs exception.

grammar_mistakes.name: Kung vs. Kapag
grammar_mistakes.description: Confusing 'kung' (“if”) and 'kapag' (“when”) based on context.

examples.correct: Matulog ka na kapag tapos na ang iyong gawain.
examples.English: Go to bed when you’re done with your work.

examples.correct: Ano ang gagawin mo kung hindi ka makapasa ng pagsusulit?
examples.English: What will you do if you don’t pass the test?

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Interchanging 'kung' and 'kapag' without context.

grammar_mistakes.name: Use of Ikaw and Ka
grammar_mistakes.description: Incorrectly swapping 'ikaw' and 'ka'; 'ka' is used more frequently in colloquial sentences.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Replacing 'ka' with 'ikaw' without understanding usage rules.

grammar_mistakes.name: Use of Mo
grammar_mistakes.description: Misusing 'mo' as a pronoun; 'mo' can mean “your” or “you” depending on context.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Confusing 'mo' with other second-person forms like 'ka' or 'ikaw'.

grammar_mistakes.name: Pinto vs. Pintuan
grammar_mistakes.description: Using 'pintuan' instead of 'pinto' for a literal door; '-an' often indicates a place, not the object.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Incorrectly generalizing words with '-an' suffix without understanding semantics.

grammar_mistakes.name: Sa akin not Sakin
grammar_mistakes.description: Incorrectly combining 'sa' and 'akin' into one word like 'sakin'.

examples.note: two separate words or stylized as 'sa’kin'.

grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Fusing separate words incorrectly (e.g., palang, parin, nalang).

grammar_mistakes.name: Filipino vs. Tagalog Label
grammar_mistakes.description: Mistaking the terms 'Filipino' and 'Tagalog' as the same. Filipino is the national language.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Referring to the national language as Tagalog instead of Filipino.

grammar_mistakes.name: Not Practicing Enough
grammar_mistakes.description: Failing to practice Filipino regularly can be one of the biggest mistakes learners make.
grammar_mistakes.common_errors: Neglecting regular speaking and writing practice.
